story:
Welcome

Welcome

Welcome to the Rescues documentary film fundraising page!  My name is Ed Foster and I’m looking for help financing post-production work on my thirty-minute documentary film, Rescues.  Our target goal is to raise $10,000 for color work and sound mixing in preparation for our festival run.  Thank you for your support.

Film Synopsis

Rescues is a thirty-minute documentary that examines the emotional and financial impact on animal rescue workers. The film follows two women as they help animals find their Forever Homes.  Donna is a hairdresser who runs Susie’s Hope Animal Rescue in High Point, NC. With enormous vet bills and an overwhelming desire to help animals, Donna must be in a constant state of fundraising. If donations start to fall off will Donna be able to continue her life’s passion or will she succumb to financial weight as so many other rescue groups have?
Linda lives in Cumming, GA and is a volunteer foster mom for Kodi’s Club Rottweiler Rescue based in Pennsylvania. Linda has just spent nine months rehabilitating Ruger. Now Linda must let go of him so he can finish his journey to his Forever Home. Will she be able to move past this emotionally draining experience and continue her work as a foster parent?
Rescues takes an unflinching look at what it takes to work in this demanding field. Hopefully, the film will raise awareness of the financial and mental health support needs for those in the animal care field.

Producer’s Statement

Most of my best friends in my life have been dogs and for the most part my dogs have come from Rescues. Like most of the general public I assumed that animal rescue work must be a never-ending source of joy. They go into the shelter and pull any number of dogs and cats to shuttle off to waiting, caring families. Although those parts exist, there are horrors beyond that idyllic veil. This is one of the hardest jobs in the world. For the most part it is a voluntary occupation that is financially draining and emotionally taxing. Every year volunteers across the US will leave creating a vacuum of need for thousands of animals. It is my hope that this film will raise awareness of the issues facing those who bring us our best friends.

Goal

After two years of filming, and eight months of editing, I need $10,000 for color work and sound mixing.  Any additional funds will be used for festival entry fees, outreach programs, and educational screenings.

Rewards

This is not a “merch” film.  The mission of this film is to raise awareness of the challenges facing animal rescue workers.  Therefore, the perks are not extravagant.   However, each pledge tier perk includes all lower tiers.  Ex. If you choose the Community Screening perk it includes the ability to stream the film before it hits festivals, the digital poster, and your name in the film's credits.  Thank you for your support of this important documentary film.

Pledge $25 or more

Your Name in the Film's Credits

See your name on-screen.  We will include you on our Donors section of the credits.

Pledge $50 or more

Digital Poster Download

Enjoy a custom PDF of the film's poster.

Pledge $100 or more

Stream Rescues before it hits the Film Festivals.

(delivered by private Vimeo link)

Pledge $250 or more

Community Screening License.

You or your group can license a local screening.

Pledge $500 or more

Private Zoom Screening with the Producer.

You and/or your group can schedule a virtual screening with the film’s producer.

Pledge $1000 or more

Associate Producer Credit

A truly incredible donation.

For your generous contribution, you will be named an Associate Producer in the credits of the film as well as the film's IMDB page.

Producer Bio

Whether it was listening to my grandmother regale the family at the dinner table with  tales of some unfortunate, distant, relative or a trip to a distant land through the pages of a book, I have always been drawn to stories and storytellers. During my high school years in Wilmington, NC I participated in theatre and forensics. I graduated from Western Carolina University with a BA in English. Shortly after that, I obtained my MA in African-American Literature from North Carolina A&T State University.  I taught college courses for ten years before returning to school and receiving my MFA in Documentary Film from Wake Forest University. I live in Greensboro, NC with my family and our five rescue dogs.

.

.

story:
Old Friends, New Home...

In March of 2020, we held the sold-out World Premiere of SENIORS A DOGUMENTARY at the gorgeous Belcourt Theatre in Nashville.  If you own the DVD to that first film, you've probably watched the star studded Q&A featuring everyone from the film.

(The DVD to the first Seniors film.)


It was at that time, during a dinner break with Zina and Michael Goodin, the compassionate geniuses behind the Old Friends Senior Dog Sanctuary, that they told me about their plans to move yet again into a grand new space.  This one over 4 times the size, and made from the ground up with senior dogs in mind.

I thought that was an amazing idea, and was going to leave it at that.  

And then Zina says, "We're going to close down the street and have a parade of all the dogs from the old location to the new one."  

Here's a little sneak of some of the drone footage shot of the parade.

 

 

What's a filmmaker to do?  I knew I had to film this parade.  And as I learned more about the new state-of-the-art facilities, the idea for SENIORS 2 was born.  

Another happy animal welfare film.  More dogs, more wagging tails, more smiling faces all around.

If you saw the first SENIORS A DOGUMENTARY, you KNOW you want to be a part of the second one.

Join us on this journey, and help bring this new film to life.  

(The founders and staff of the Old Friends Senior Dog Sanctuary at the ribbon cutting for their amazing new facilities on June 4th in Mount Juliet, Tennessee.)

 

(The trailer to the first Seniors film.)

Unlike most animal documentaries, our goal once again will be to highlight the positive.  No abuse will be shown in SENIORS-2.  This film will celebrate senior dogs, focusing on the love they still have left to give.   It will show how vibrant they are, and how much they can offer to the world.  This will be the animal welfare film everyone can watch, leaving viewers grinning from ear-to-ear, and showing how old dogs really can teach us new tricks.

(Zoey & Gemini, from the Old Friends Seniors Dog Sanctuary)

 

A little more about our main subjects:

Located just outside of Nashville, the Old Friends Senior Dog Sanctuary is a retirement home of sorts dedicated to saving senior dogs from sure death at shelters.  Run by Zina and Michael Goodin, and a staff of saints, the new film will dig deeper in how they've managed to turn the animal rescue world on its ear, and reinvent the way things should be done.  We will of course look at their amazing new facilities, and cover that parade, with a half-dozen cameras on the ground, and even one in the air.  

Plus we'll introduce you to the newest fur-legged rock stars of Old Friends.  And even take a look back at the god-father of senior dogs, Leo.

(Michael & Zina Goodin with Leo)

 

Why We're Making This Film

We love dogs!  We want to show how vibrant and vital dogs can be no matter their age.  (To us there is no such thing as an "old dog.")  If we can show how much senior dogs still have to offer, if we can demonstrate the bond people have with their canine friends, if this film can help one dog find a great new forever home, then we've done something wonderful. If we've made you smile, or hug your dog, then we've accomplished even more.

(Director Gorman Bechard with his senior dog Springsteen)

 

Who We Are:

Director Gorman Bechard, co-owner of What Were We Thinking Films, is a lifelong dog lover (if you have any doubt read his eulogy to his dog Kilgore Trout here).  He has numerous feature-length documentaries and narrative features to his credit.

He directed the animal welfare documentary, A DOG NAMED GUCCI, for which he was awarded the ASPCA Media Excellence Award 2015 for his work on that film.

Gorman is also the director of Color Me Obsessed, a film about The Replacements, which Rolling Stone called one of "The Seven Best New Music Documentaries of the Year."  As well as three other rock-docs: WHO IS LYDIA LOVELESS?, WHAT DID YOU EXPECT? the Archers of Loaf live at Cat's Cradle, and EVERY EVERYTHING: the music, life & times of Grant Hart.  His narrative features include the award-winning  FRIENDS (WITH BENEFITS), YOU ARE ALONE and BROKEN SIDE OF TIME, and the horror cult classic PSYCHOS IN LOVE.

Most recently he completed PIZZA A LOVE STORY, which played to sold-out crowds at film festivals across the country, and was released on DVD in the fall of 2020.

You can read an interview with Gorman Bechard in FilmMaker Magazine here.  He is also the Executive Director/Programmer of the NHdocs Film Festival, held every June in New Haven.  His full bio can be found here.

Dean Falcone, who created the amazing score for Seniors A Dogumentary using only toy instruments, will be back with something new up his musical sleeves.  Sydni Frisch, who edited the trailer you see above, will be editing this film, working with director Bechard to bring the stories to life.  And our amazing cinematographers will capture the vitality of these senior pups in vivid 4K.

Our company, the micro-studio What Were We Thinking Films, founded in 2004, has a proven track record, with over thirty years of experience making feature films.

(Alexis, from the Old Friends Seniors Dog Sanctuary)

 

Where Your Money Goes

The money raised for SENIORS-2 will go towards filming, editing, creating an amazing score, all of the things that go into making a feature film.  And much like with the last film, this will mostly likely be the first of two fund raising campaigns...unless we can really knock this out of the park.  So please share the link, tell every dog lover you know, and post it on all of your social media pages...and let's raise $50,000 instead of $25,000.  

Thank you!

(Jake, from the Old Friends Seniors Dog Sanctuary)
story_txt: Old Friends, New Home...In March of 2020, we held the sold-out World Premiere of SENIORS A DOGUMENTARY at the gorgeous Belcourt Theatre in Nashville.  If you own the DVD to that first film, you've probably watched the star studded Q&A featuring everyone from the film.(The DVD to the first Seniors film.)It was at that time, during a dinner break with Zina and Michael Goodin, the compassionate geniuses behind the Old Friends Senior Dog Sanctuary, that they told me about their plans to move yet again into a grand new space.  This one over 4 times the size, and made from the ground up with senior dogs in mind.I thought that was an amazing idea, and was going to leave it at that.  And then Zina says, "We're going to close down the street and have a parade of all the dogs from the old location to the new one."  Here's a little sneak of some of the drone footage shot of the parade.  What's a filmmaker to do?  I knew I had to film this parade.  And as I learned more about the new state-of-the-art facilities, the idea for SENIORS 2 was born.  Another happy animal welfare film.  More dogs, more wagging tails, more smiling faces all around.If you saw the first SENIORS A DOGUMENTARY, you KNOW you want to be a part of the second one.Join us on this journey, and help bring this new film to life.  (The founders and staff of the Old Friends Senior Dog Sanctuary story:
Overview

Jesus, who has been on a self-imposed sabbatical in the mortal world, is warned of an impending threat to the human race. The 4 Warlords of the apocalypse, deadly demonic gangs who control evil on earth, are planning to put their armies together for the final overthrow of humankind. But this isn't a biblical tale, this film is set in the modern world, and Jesus is a conflicted man, a master of combat and martial arts who assembles a group of mercenaries to battle the forces of Lucifer.

Is this a faith-based feel-good movie?

Really????

NOPE. It's raw, high-octane action turning the tables on folklore, religion, and tradition.

Cinema Lexzikon is the ONLY indie film company in the Midwest that has had 3 back to back releases through Red Box, the world's largest automated DVD movie platform. REDBOX is now expanding to ON DEMAND, and Cinema Lexzikon wants to provide content for that platform.

Our previous film 6 FEET BELOW HELL was a top-rated action feature at Redbox for more than 3 years! Few Hollywood films remain at Redbox for that length of time!

The film is now one of the top-rated action/horror films on Tubi TV:

https://tubitv.com/movies/576964/6-feet-below-hell?start=true

BOTTOM LINE: We start what we finish!

 

EVEN WITH UNPRECEDENTED SUCCESS, Cinema Lexzikon is not always able to convince our investment group to ante up the funds needed for production. This is the one and only reason we run Indiegogo campaigns. We do not like it, we appreciate donations, and we'd rather do it on our own. But as we have seen, even famous Hollywood types use this platform to raise capital. Surely, if they can raise millions, we'd hope raising a few thousand would be a  no-brainer. Hollywood will not help us. WIll you?

What We Need & What You Get

SIMPLE:

PERKS PERKS PERKS!!!

Along with the normal perks, this time around we have something special:

In July of this year, VINEGAR SYNDROME in collaboration with

The American Genre Film Archive is releasing William Lee's 1987 cult classic Treasure of The Ninja as a restored Blu-Ray disc retrospective!

Check the perks list and make sure you get your autographed copy by selecting the appropriate perks!

We hope to reach our goal, but if we don't we shall persevere. We always have and we always will.

The Impact

No Hollywood company would give us the money. 

Even with the success of FATE OF THE FURIOUS and BLACK PANTHER,  Hollywood still fails to give black films wide release or budgets to make diverse cinema.

William Lee employs color-blind, gender-blind casting in each and every film. This one is no different. We think that's important.

We want to change the paradigm of filmmaking, by making movies look like AMERICA. Not some Hollywood billionaire's idea of his own "perfect" world. Cinema Lexzikon puts unlikely heroes in positions of power.  We think that's important. Or maybe we should just give up and leave it as business as usual.

Uh, no. We won't.

Cinema Lexzikon has taken budgets under $10,000 for a feature film and produced films that have generated revenue of more than 3 times the cost of the projects. Ask any Hollywood producer how much they'd like their films to do that all the time.

For more information ON US, GO HERE: www.cinemalexzikon.com

And visit the official website now under construction:  BULLETRPOOF WEBSITE

Risks & Challenges

There is always the risk that our film will not get a full release or may not be released at all. That is the film business. Regardless, we usually find an avenue to get the film shown and distributed. THIS IS THE FILM BUSINESS. We cannot guarantee success, but we guarantee the film will be finished, and you will get your perks.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share all over social media. At least 2 times weekly. We ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign if money is tight. Sometimes a referral to a film company, or other organizations that might be willing to help us out with food donations, material items, or mentions in large-scale websites, blogs, and magazines, radio, podcasts, etc. are always a big deal.

And be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
** Update, February 2021: The easiest way to purchase the finished film:

www.thismighthurtfilm.com

 

You can also sign up on our site to host or attend virtual screenings, which we highly recommend! They're so fun.

Another option is you can also purchase the film by selecting "Stream the Film" in the column to the right-hand side. A second email with a streaming link to the film will be emailed within 24 hours. --->

This Might Hurt and the special features are now finished and ready to be emailed. We're able to continue offering a chance to see the film before it's officially released, and we can accept donations through this site, or you can go through our tax-deductible sponsor, Fractured Atlas. We're working to raise an additional $120,000 for our impact and distribution campaign. Please join us!

What people have said about the film:

- "Powerful and engaging in the way it showed the human stories while also being informative and skillfully filmed."

-"The definitive film on chronic pain."

- "It gave a very balanced view, as it included interviews with other doctors and didn’t seek to push a particular point."

- "I just showed the film for 10 [healthcare professional] students, and they loved it. It raised a lot of questions around difficulties with patients."

- "A 'must-see' movie for chronic pain patients & their loved ones."

- "This Might Hurt moved me to tears."

 

Photo from a Q &A at a rough cut screening with the International Documentary Association

(Full Trailer)

This Might Hurt is an intimate vérité film that follows three chronic pain patients who have spent years trying to cure their illness through modern medicine without success. Desperate for relief, they enter an unconventional medicine program — run by Dr. Howard Schubiner — that focuses on uncovering hidden causes of pain, and retraining their brains to switch the pain off.

The film follows them through initial evaluations with Dr. Schubiner, their skepticism of his approach, and revelatory group sessions. As they go through ups and downs over years, each of them makes astonishing discoveries about the nature of their pain.

Each contributor will help us bring this film to others, and we'd love it if you could share this film with your friends and family to help spread the word!

THE SCIENCE BEHIND THIS UNIQUE TREATMENT

While only a handful of doctors are aware of the treatment shown in this film, it’s quickly gaining recognition. The treatment—known as EAET—was featured on NPR, shown to be effective in a large randomized controlled trial, and recognized as a “pain management best practice” by the NIH’s task force to combat the opioid epidemic. This Might Hurt provides an in-depth exploration of this cutting-edge treatment, through immersion with one of its inventors.

 

Over 50 million Americans suffer from chronic pain and the opioid epidemic is ravaging the nation. We need better ways of helping people who are suffering. Could this treatment, which turns conventional medical wisdom on its head, be part of the solution?

But we believe this film is also relevant for anyone who experiences pain. Close to 80% of Americans will have chronic pain at some point in their lives, and we all know someone who is affected. People we’ve shown the film to have often said something like, my uncle or my sister-in-law needs to see this. And while pain can be a downer, we think learning about the mind-body connection is powerful, and hopeful.

 

Production on This Might Hurt began several years ago, and we’ve been supported by the New York State Council for the Arts. We've had a world premiere at the Austin Film Festival and we're raising money to engage partners who want to use this film as a tool to educate patients about how chronic pain really works.

Our aim is to raise at least $120,000 to pay for an impact producer, digital marketing, and distribution, so we can get the film to the people who need it most!

 

Donations via Indiegogo are unfortunately not tax-deductible. But we invite you to make a tax-deductible contribution via our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas.

 

 

Director Marion Cunningham is a filmmaker who has produced series for Netflix, National Geographic, Fusion, Animal Planet, and A&E. She’s currently the Supervising Producer of OZY Studios.

Director Kent Bassett is an Emmy-nominated editor and filmmaker from Arizona. He’s edited a number of feature documentaries that have premiered at Tribeca Film Festival, AFI Docs, Doc NYC, and on PBS. His most recent film as editor is Not Going Quietly (Tribeca), about a 32-year-old father, Ady Barkan, who after being diagnosed with ALS travels the country to fight for universal health care.

Much of the drive to make This Might Hurt came from Kent’s own struggle with debilitating arm pain as a 22-year-old. Unable to type on a computer or even turn a doorknob, he had to drop out of college. Although he saw several doctors and tried physical therapy, strength training, even narcotics—the pain grew steadily worse. It wasn’t until he had an insight into the role of stress that he was able to completely recover.

 

Dr. Howard Schubiner has been treating chronic pain patients for nearly two decades, during which time he has been developing and refining his mind-body approach. He is recognized as a leading researcher and physician in the field of pain medicine. He has authored more than 100 publications, including an NIH-funded study on fibromyalgia for the journal PAIN. He is on the board of the PPDA, which advances the diagnosis and treatment of stress-induced medical conditions. He is now working with neuroscientists at the University of Colorado at Boulder on a neuroimaging study for people with back pain.

The late Dr. John Sarno was a professor of rehabilitation medicine at New York University. He was a pioneer of the mind-body field (and a mentor to Dr. Schubiner) who wrote books like Healing Back Pain that were accessible to the lay reader who wanted to learn about pain. Among the thousands of patients he treated are Howard Stern, Larry David, and John Stossel.

Tony has suffered from debilitating leg pain since he was 12. In the last five years, he’s had to stop playing basketball and attending school. The dozens of doctors he’s visited can only tell him that he has Chronic Regional Pain Syndrome, which typically has no cure and no known cause. Once he turns eighteen, he is likely to be prescribed opioids. This is when he meets Dr. Schubiner.

Maureen is a writer, working on a book about the Great Lakes, an area she loves. But she suffers from severe pain in her hands that makes it hard to type, and has also prevented her from getting a full night of sleep for years. After physical therapy doesn't work, she is told that her final option is neck surgery followed by a long recovery period, during which she’d be dependent on opioids for pain management.

Kym used to ride motorcycles and worked at an auto parts supplier. But then her abdominal pain and fibromyalgia became so severe that she’s spent the last 8 years in bed rest, disabled. While she currently depends on opioids to manage her pain, and on her mother to help with the household, she hopes to return to a full life where she can play with her nieces and nephews, and be of service to others.

 

Because we've finished the film, the risks are low. The only issue is if we don't raise enough money, our outreach and distribution won't reach people who could benefit.

THANK YOU SO INCREDIBLY MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!

But then her abdominal pain and fibromyalgia became so severe that she’s spent the last 8 years in bed rest, disabled. While she currently depends on opioids to manage her pain, and on her mother to help with the household, she hopes to return to a full life where she can play with her nieces and nephews, and be of service to others. Because we've finished the film, the risks are low. The only issue is if we don't raise enough money, our outreach and distribution won't reach people who could benefit.THANK YOU SO INCREDIBLY MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!

story:
Story Synopsis

Samantha is 22-year-old music composing student who wants to create a piece of music to graduate. She moves into her college dorm in the hope of escaping a troubled home life. Introverted and bitter, Samantha wonders if she can actually become a successful musician. While alone in her dorm room, Samantha hears an eastern melody playing next door. She decides to find the player.

Why This Film? Why Now?

"She Does Not Smile" is a film that deals with contemporary social topics through the lens of a love story. Comprised of a highly diverse and ambitious team, this film aims to bring awareness to US immigration policies during the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Our team will create a film that celebrates diverse music while also tackling the everyday implications of pandemic-era US politics and the impact they had on international students. Our contributors will help our team develop this passion project, and in turn, tell a story that is often neglected in other films. 

Director's Statement

As an Iranian international student in the US, I have experienced the limitation to see my family because of the travel ban policy which is imposed on some countries including Iran. This is the love story that reacts to the US immigration law which influenced the life of international students. On the other hand, Afghanistan and Iran (my homeland) are neighbor countries. These two countries have similar cultures, similar music, and similar languages. So, I am the right person to narrate this story with a taste of migration in the U.S. However, I do not want to just make a one-layer film. As the themes of this short are Love, Music, Students life, Pandemic, Politics, War, Iran, Afghanistan, and the US, this multi-layer story can be interesting for different audiences of different nationalities and ages around the world.

- Zardosht Afshari, Writer/Director

The Team

Zardosht Afshari, Writer/Director

Zardosht Afshari is an Iranian filmmaker who has had films screened in international film festivals. Zardosht's work has been screened in countries like the US, Iran, Poland, Croatia, India, and Italy. He received his MA in dramatic literature from the University of Tehran. He moved to the United States 2019. Currently living in Philadelphia, Zardosht is enrolled in Temple University's Film & Media Arts MFA program. 

 

 

 

Madison Conner, Producer

Madison Conner is an emerging filmmaker with a concentration in producing and assistant directing. she got her start on the sketch comedy show Temple Smash as a PA then working her way up to executive producer. After college, Madison started working as a production coordinator for the the amazon prime series "The Fourth Wall". Currently Madison has two films in post-production "Memnon" and "What Happened at the Top of the Smokestack". Madison is also working as a production assistant to Adam Sandler on the new Netflix film "Hustle".

 

Saba Ahmed, Director of Photography

Saba Ahmed is a Philadelphia based cinematographer and recent alumni of Temple University. Recent projects over the past year include “Fire in an Empty Room”, “Khwab Ki Takmeel”, and “Bipartite”. The most exciting part of “She Does Not Smile” for them is showcasing different cultural aspects of the college experience through our main characters perspective.

 

 

 

 

Our Goal

Our fundraising goal for "She Does Not Smile" is $15,000

  • All funds go to the film, regardless of reaching our $15,000 goal.
  • Check out our perks to see what you receive after your donation!

Risks & Challenges

Our team acknowledges and considers every risk and challenge that goes into making every film. This is especially true during COVID-19.

  • Making a film during the pandemic:
    • Every person on our team has had experience working on film sets throughout this COVID-19 era. We feel supremely confident in our ability to not only create a high quality film, but to do so safely.
      • This includes rigorous testing, mask wearing, and hand washing policies that will be strictly enforced throughout the production. The safety of our cast & crew is our top priority.
  • Not reaching our fundraising goal:
    • While we feel strongly that we can reach our $15K goal, we are also a flexible campaign. This means that we keep whatever you donate, regardless of whether or not we reach our goal.
      • Our team has put in the preparation to ensure that this film will be made. We will adapt to whatever our financial situation after our 60 days of fundraising.
      • With that said, every little bit helps us make a higher quality film! We encourage everyone to donate, and/or to share our campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any little bit helps! That includes sharing our campaign across social media. Spread the word about "She Does Not Smile"!

  • Use Indiegogo's share tools to easily share the campaign on social media.
  • Follow the film's Instagram @shedoesnotsmilefilm.
  • Share our Instagram posts with your friends, family, and fellow film lovers.

We appreciate every contribution to "She Does Not Smile", whether you donate to our campaign or just spread the word. This film does not happen without you!

story:
Short Summary

We did it! We have reached our target on Indiegogo and we would like to thank everyone who supported, shared and especially donated! We could not have done this without you and we are so happy that you are part of this journey with us. 

BUT!

We have kept the donations open, simply because £15,000 is a tight budget, the more money we can raise, the better chance the short films have re: production quality, casting and crew and also being part of the international film festival, which gives these talented deaf creatives an opportunity to be seen and heard through their short films worldwide.

 

Who We Are.

Hear Art is a non-profit platform in partnership with The Royal Association for Deaf people (RAD), The British Short Film Awards and Academy-Award winner Slick Films Ltd. Hear Art funds and mentors deaf filmmakers, helping them to create independent short films that will reach all film lovers, both in the deaf and the hearing community. These short films will show how much richer our artistic landscape is, when the business of making film, is fully committed to inclusivity and accessibility. It will challenge communication in front and behind the lens and open up a dialogue about employment and opportunities in the Arts and Media. 

This platform allows deaf creatives to tell their own stories or explore their imagination through film, which will give a unique insight and perspective to film making. What is great about this project is bringing deaf and hearing creatives together to work and prove that communication can be overcome and we all can provide an inclusive space for everyone. 

With the help of your kind contribution, we will be able to communicate Hear Art films to a broader audience and secure funding for filming and production costs.

Please meet our three film directors whose short film you will be funding:

Bim Ajadi.

​"Its a great way of bridging two different communities; the deaf world and the mainstream and to provide a space for them to collaborate".

Short Film: Night Shift.

A Deaf, female security guard on the night shift observes a man in the midst of a crisis; they find a new way to communicate.

 

Cathy Heffernan.

"Im invoved in this project as I am passionate about seeing deaf and hearing people work together".

Short Film: Hair Uncovered.

When artist Maral Mamaghani cut off her own hair and used it to create brooches to display, she was defying the regime she grew up under – and setting herself free.

 

Brian Duffy.

"Historically, Deaf TV and sign language around the world, has been left behind. My hope is that through Hear Art we can make significant steps to close the gap".

Short Film: One Letter.

A man reunites with his deaf cousin at a family gathering - and long-simmering tensions and resentments come to the boil.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our total to raise is £30,000, the fantastic news is that we only need to raise an extra £15,000 for the project and have already reached our half way point! Your money will contribute to making the films in regards to cast, crew, production and also BSL interpreters on set.

Hear Art will publish all the expenses on our website as we believe in transparency and building a trustful relationship to everyone who have supported us.

We have garnered praise and support from Joanna Lumley, Will Poulter, Kae Tempest, La Roux, Maxine Peake, Sleaford Mods, Baxter Dury, Fearne Cotton, Vivienne Westwood, Joe Corre, Guy Chambers and many more.

 

The Impact

Hear Art wants to challenge the current status quo and inspire the deaf and disability community that they can achieve whatever they want in the arts and creative industry. We want to prove that accessibility and inclusiveness can be integrated successfully within a work and social environment.

 

Risks & Challenges

Hear Art will team hearing producers with deaf directors and challenge the wider conversation on communication and the importance of sign language. These producers have never worked with deaf filmmakers before and some of our directors have never directed hearing actors. There is nervous exciting energy around this and we look forward to updating you on how it comes along.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand the past year has been very difficult for everyone, if you can't donate then you can help by sharing and posting our Indiegogo campaign on your social media platforms and using #hearart. Thank you from all of us.
