We are so excited to create this film, but we need your help to do so!The Film:In 1977, roommates Kristen, Jean, and Shannon are beginning to be taunted by an unseen supernatural force. This begins to highlight the hidden conflict between Jean and Shannon, with Kristen in the middle. But as the entity begins to further target Kristen, personal issues must be put aside in order to save their friend before it is too late.  Director's Statement:"A familial bond is a powerful thing. Sometimes too powerful. Someone can your best friend, but can turn into your worst enemy upon moving in together. With many of us spending a lot of time at home recently, it’s surely been on everyone’s mind. Dead Girl is a film about good friends and bad roommates, and a film for those of us who have hated someone just as much as they loved them."  The Team:Jake Marston (Writer/Director)Jake Marston is the writer and director of Dead Girl, who wanted to make a film for good friends who might be bad roommates. Jake directed Verde last fall and is now excited to use  his previous filmmaking experience to make Dead Girl the best film possible.Jaiden Turner (Producer)Jaiden Turner is a senior in MSU's film program and producer for Dead Girl. She has previously directed a short film Breathe and is a four time recipient of the Taco Bell Live Mas Scholarship for her passion for storytelling. Jaiden can't wait to work with this team, and she is so excited to help bring Dead Girl to life!Zach Robinson (Director of Photography)Zach is the cinematographer for Dead Girl and is very excited to bring Jake's vision to reality. He's worked on several student films before and is excited to work with this solid crew for this project. He can't wait to show what he and Jake have planned for Dead Girl!
Chandler Pippin (Editor)Currently a senior at Montana State University, Chandler has fasten in love with experimental filmmaking and editing. They take lots of inspiration from films like Nobuhiku Obayashi's House, and plans to take cues from such works when editing Dead Girl. He's thrilled to be working with Jake again, as he has proven to be a capable director who is a pleasure to edit for, and excited to work with a stellar crew.Sienna Riley (Production Design)Sienna Riley is a senior at Montana State hoping to pursue production design post grad. Her love of film can be traced to shows like That 70s Show so she is so excited to create an exciting 70s aesthetic with sorority inspiration from her own sorority scrapbooks.  Budget BreakdownTotal Budget: $3,500Production Design - $1000Production design is a huge part of our film; this includes everything from hair and makeup, to costumes, special effects. We also need to give our modern location the look and feel of the 70s vibes of Dead Girl with props and set decorations.Equipment - $500As film students at Montana State University, we are lucky enough to have access to the film department's equipment from cameras to lights and sound equipment. But, we still need rent additional equipment to help create the world of Dead Girl.Acting - $500In order to cast the best actors possible, we need to be able to pay them for their time; their time and commitment throughout the pre-production, and production process deserves reward!Food - $600During this time, we must feed meals, and snacks to our crew to ensure they perform their best on set. With COVID still being prevalent, we also need to take into consideration meals that can be individually packaged for our cast and crew.COVID - $200While COVID is still prevalent in our world, safety is one of our top priorities. We need to make sure we can make Dead Girl while also staying as safe as possible by purchasing all the necessary PPE and supplies to keep our cast and crew safe and healthy.Marketing/Distribution - $500Marketing will allow us to promote our film, and make sure it gets out into the world.  This includes creating posters, social media promotions, and other promotional materials. The next step is to submit Dead Girl to film festivals so it can be seen by the world.Expendables - $200Some items such as tape, gels, and batteries that must be purchased to create our film. Without these little things, our film won't be possible! Risks & ChallengesCOVID-19 presents challenges that everyone in our world is facing on a daily basis. However, our team is working hard to ensure we can create our film while still following health and safety guidelines.  Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. Spread the word! We would love it if you shared our IndieGoGo, or Instagram page! @deadgirl_film

story:
How We Got Here

Thank you so much for taking the time to visit the "Into Nowhere" campaign page! My name is Natalie Slone; I'm the producer and screenwriter on this project. It's been such a joy to be a part of this film.

The reason "Into Nowhere" exists is because of the director, Bennett Morton, a film student at Middle Tennessee State University. I met Bennett on a set in January. We became fast friends, and shortly after, he asked me to write a script for him to direct. Spoiler alert: I agreed. After taking inspiration from films like Frances Ha (Noah Baumbach, 2013) and Whisper of the Heart (Yoshifumi Kondo, 1995), "Into Nowhere" was born.

One of my favorite things about the arts is the ability to collaborate with others. We've partnered with Nashville DP* and gaffer, Jarrett Jarvis, as well as award-winning composer Kennoniah Bellile to help us bring this story to life. When it comes to our crew, our goal is to invest in students by giving them an opportunity to develop their skills on a set where they can be proud of the result.

*DP = Director of Photography

The Film

"Into Nowhere" is a slice-of-life short film. It revolves around Elle and Brett, two long-time friends in their mid-20's whose jobs and relationships have caused them to drift apart. After Elle has a tough day, Brett off-handedly suggests she go for a drive to clear her mind. Little does he realize she'll heed his advice. . .and take him along for the ride! 

In the isolation of the car, they not only face the reality of their individual situations, but they also confront the effects their situations have had on their relationship. This is a story of a rekindled friendship and learning to live in limbo.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5000 in order to make this film the best it can be. With this amount, we'll be able to accomplish more in terms of casting actors, renting equipment, and investing in post-production quality.

On to my favorite part! We'll be sending you a variety of rewards packages to thank you for each donation we receive. We have a lot of exciting perks such as stickers, film posters, exclusive behind-the-scenes vlogs, first access to the finished film, and more! The rewards packages are cumulative, so if you order a $50 package, you will receive all the items included up to $50.

*The Budget: $5000

Actors: $1000

Equipment/Car Rigging: $700

Post-Production: $800

Music: $800

Sound: $700

Crafty: $500

Location: $200

Props: $100

Festival Submissions: $200

*Budget subject to change.

The Impact

Our story has a message. Its purpose is to provide a wholesome film which leaves the audience feeling encouraged and hopeful. We live in a world where unity is scarce, and it doesn't take much for a relationship to drift apart. With our story, we want to impact people's hearts. If we can accomplish that within even one person, I'll say, "Mission accomplished."

Also, by investing in this film, you'll be investing in the next generation of filmmakers and storytellers. By hiring actors and crew department heads who are established in their craft, we can give film students some hands-on set opportunity.

We need your help in order to make it happen. This is the largest amount of money I've attempted to raise, and it's the project with the highest stakes to date. On top of everything involved with production, we plan on going all-out with the films' festival submissions.

When it comes to festivals, last year, my short film, "The Grand Inquisitor," was accepted to two local festivals (Nashville Edge Film Festival and the Southeast International Film Festival) and a film I wrote, "Nina," won the Audience Award and the Lipscomb 5-Minute Film Festival. This time, in addition to the local festivals, we're aiming big for the Sundance Film Festival (among many others)!

Risks & Challenges

It's no secret that film making is not an easy task. Due to the film's setting being a road trip, there are some logistical hoops we must jump through with the assistance of a variety of resources: camera tricks, equipment, set pieces; your donations will help us acquire the resources, and we'll put in the time to figure out the quirks of our logistics in the months leading up to production.

In addition to the standard resources required for a film, those listed above in the proposed budget, we also need to make sure we have the ability to accommodate safety on set. Though we are on the back-end of the pandemic, set safety is still a priority of ours. When we get closer to production, we will check the recommended CDC guidelines for a safe production to ensure the health of our crew.

Other Ways You Can Help

Know that every little bit helps! And please SPREAD THE WORD!

If you're unable to contribute financially, tell your friends! Share that link to social media, post an Insta-story, or follow @slone_films on Instagram, where you can see production updates. We are grateful for any support you're able to give. Knowing just that you're interested means the world to us.

Thank you again for taking the time to read this conglomerate of information about our upcoming film! We appreciate you so much.

- Natalie Slone, Writer/Producer

 

CHECK OUT OUR PREVIOUS WORKS HERE:
